subject: Re: [junit] Re:How to use JUnit return String[]
msgSnippet: Hi, please start a new thread for a new topic. ... This does not even compile! Please provide a working minimal example. From my crystal ball I d say you try
messageBody:
Hi,


please start a new thread for a new topic.

On Monday 22 March 2004 13:17, kavitha arumugam wrote:
> Java Code:
> public String[] getMandatoryParameters(){
> return new String[]{"SourceString"};
> }
>
> JUnit code: here testclass calling java class already
> initialized in setup
> public void testgetMandatoryParameters()
> {
> String getMandatoryParam = {"SourceString"};
> assertEquals( testClass.getMandatoryParameters ),
> getMandatoryParam);
> }

This does not even compile!
Please provide a working minimal example.

From my crystal ball I'd say you try to assign an Array to a String, which
can not work.

I don't see why returning arrays should work different in JUnit and plain
Java. Once you fixed the compilation problems, you may also run into
trouble when you compare String[]s: JUnit does not perform a by-element
comparison, you may want to take a look at ArrayAssert in the
JUnit-Addons (http://junitaddons.sourceforge.net).


Robert
